>> =
Consider the template code:

>>=

  MyClass that =3D (MyClass) other;
>>         // compare fields or whateve=
r you like

>>=
 
>> I claim that this implementation of equals fully supports the

act of Object#equals, including the subclass/superclass case. If

nk that is false, then please show us a test consistent with
>> the contrac=
t of Object#equals that this implementation does not pass.
>
>Okay, java.ut=
il HashSets and TreeSets.
>
>According to the contract for the Equals metho=
d on the Set Interface, a
>Set is equal to another set if they are the same=
 size, and both contain
>the same objects.
>
>Your implementation would ret=
urn false in this case if one set were a
>TreeSet and the other were a Hash=
Set, as the class objects aren't
>equal.  
>
>We could say that, in Bloch's=
 original example with points, the real
>problem is that the ColoredPoint i=
s changing the contract of the equals
>method.  And, in fact, this is proba=
bly what he means by the "add an
>aspect" portion of his statement "There i=
s simply no way to extend an
>instantiable class and add an aspect while pr=
eserving the equals
>contract."

Yes. I think we're in total agreement here=
